Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Artificial Intelligence, Scientific Reasoning, and Formative Feedback: Structuring Success for STEM Students
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project uses artificial intelligence techniques to identify the ways that undergraduate students in scientific courses explicate problems, describe procedures, make claims, provide evidence, offer qualifications, and draw conclusions. With emphasis on forms of scientific reasoning, this new use of artificial intelligence, to identify language patterns associated with scientific reasoning, will allow students to improve their written laboratory reports before they are submitted, therefore freeing instructors to devote precious instructional time to preparing students for roles as practicing scientists. As the U.S. continues to experience rapid diversity growth, this focus on helping students through innovative uses of technology holds the potential to expand science education by cultivating student ability through autonomous writing and revision. Because artificial intelligence techniques are intended to expand capabilities, the techniques being used, available 24/4 on the web, will have the direct impact of growing our technical and scientific workforce, thus expanding the many dynamic pathways to STEM occupations. As the NSF observed in 2015 in its report Revisiting the STEM Workforce, these jobs are extensive and critical to innovation and competitiveness and are essential to the mutually reinforcing goals of individual and national prosperity and competitiveness. An investment in such a technology is thus an investment in national competitiveness, education policy, innovation, and workforce diversity.

NSF SBIR support will be used to design and launch artificial intelligence techniques based on Deep Artificial Neural Network (DANN) as driven by Natural Language Processing (NLP), Latent Semantic Analysis (LSA), and the latest advances in AI algorithms. Because NLP and LSA techniques are presently used solely to identify grammatical and organizational patterns, the application of DANN is high risk in making a leap from identifying patterns of language use to capturing patterns of scientific reasoning. Trained on a proprietary corpus of 100,000 lab reports scored and annotated by instructors and students using a single rubric, the AI application will identify logic structures of scientific reasoning in student laboratory reports. Once methodically identified, categorized according to ability level, and validated by STEM instructors, digital instruction will be used to help students improve their scientific reasoning processes. With the singular goal of structuring student success through asynchronous machine learning, this innovation holds the promise to figure meaningfully in discussions of national competitiveness, education policy, innovation, and diversity as related to STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Part 1: Intellectual Merit

Between 07/01/2017 and 06/30/2018, the My Reviewers, LLC, team designed and validated an automated scoring and feedback (AFS) system for STEM writing in undergraduate chemistry courses. Using machine learning and artificial neural network models, the team built a system capable of the following:

  • providing automated feedback to first-year chemistry students, based on best instructor commenting practices, to defined sections of laboratory reports; and
  • providing scores, based on rubric of performance levels, to students and their instructors.

Once approved by the instructor—a human-in-the-loop approach—grades can then be assigned to the reports. The designed models achieved up to 100% accuracy with human scores for automated scoring (required for quantitative, rubric based levels of performance), up to 98% for automated splitting of laboratory reports into sections (required for placement of feedback comments into appropriate sections of the laboratory report); and up to 90% for automated feedback (required for actionable student revision based on instructor commenting practices).

In essence, the AFS system is a technological innovation designed to enhance students STEM learning. Use of technology to support writing instruction, especially in STEM undergraduate courses, is an area that is largely unexplored. The potential impact of the AFS system is therefore substantial.

Part 2:  Broader Impacts

The SBIR represents a significant advancement of data resources and the acquisition of data skills. Attendant with the emergence of massive data analysis, the AFS systems represents a significant advancement in feedback and scoring involving written communication. The kind of multidisciplinary collaboration involved in the study suggests new career paths in involving data science used for pedagogical purposes.

In computer science and writing studies, the design and validation of the AFS system suggests new ways to use information to improve student learning. In terms of massive data analysis, the approaches used here provide new directions for the design and validation of data warehouse construction. As well, the pedagogical directions for STEM learning are significantly advanced by automated scoring and feedback of written communication. In terms of resource allocation, the time saving here is enormous in terms of instructor marking and scoring of laboratory reports. Since the AFS has proven accurate in scoring, text section identification, and automated feedback, instructor time can be spent on working with students to ensure that cognitive, interpersonal, and intrapersonal domains not addressed by the AFS system are encouraged in students to advance learning.

With resources devoted to technological development, new divisions can be created in institutional research and planning devoted to, where possible, automation of learning to encourage STEM advancement. While thus SBIR funded initiative has been devoted to laboratory reports in chemistry, similar systems can be constructed and validated in other STEM areas with other key writing genres. With the development and wise use of such technologies, institutional resources can be devoted to forms of deep learning that are not covered by the features identified in the AFS system. Technologies such as ours can enable STEM instructors to allocate time wisely, especially in terms of advanced knowledge and skills that can be attained once writing skills are firmly in place and pursued with confidence by students.

While the present SBIR has focused exclusively on the genre of the laboratory report in undergraduate chemistry courses, it appears feasible that the approach we have taken can be used in other STEM disciplines and genres, as well as in other non-stem academic disciplines. If further experimentation proves useful, then the automated feedback and scoring approach used in this SBIR had important implications for technology transfer across disciplines and genres where written communication is viewed as important to student success.
